div1.p: [Frost] sends carbons of typed manuscript chapters from the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Wade Hampton Frost] to Laura Armistead Carter, August 27, 1930
div1.opener:
THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
SCHOOL OF HYGIENE AND PUBLIC HEALTH
615 NORTH WOLFE STREET
DEPARTMENT OF EPIDEMIOLOGY
BALTIMORE, MD.
August 27, 1930.
My dear Miss Laura:
div1.p:
I am enclosing for you carbons of three additional
chapters which the typist has finished, and which you have
not seen. Unless there are major corrections to be made
it is unnecessary to return them.

Am also enclosing pages to precede the regularly num-
bered pages of the MS, namely: Title page, author's preface,
and editors' note which is really part of the preface. This
is, of course, drafted subject to your approval. The acknowl-
edgements are not as extensive perhaps as you suggested, but
I believe they include all (except perhaps Dr. Spinden) who
have actually and directly contributed anything that goes into
the book. To acknowledge all the interest and courtesy shown
seems to me manifestly impossible; and I think a too voluminous
list of acknowledgements detracts from the significance of those
made.

I have prepared, to be included if eventually so decided,
a final summary chapter, made up partly from your Father's
notes, but largely from the narrative itself; also have written
the needed note on recent experimental studies which ought to
be inserted in Part I.

I am afraid we ought to insert as an editorial note, added to
Chapter V Morley's extracts from the Tizimin MS and their trans-
lations as given by him in his letter of January 1929. In
view of the late date of the letter it could only be introduced
as a note. It is probably of no great importance, for I can not
think that those Maya records are of much significance, one way
or the other, but since the translations are more or less in dis-
pute it is fairer to give these alternative versions, and more
courteous to Morley, who dug them up. I have the necessary data
and can prepare the note which then can be either omitted otr
included as need be.

My typist continues slow, and I fear will not have finished
by the end of this week, but at least she is careful and indust-
rious.

With best regards to you and Miss Brown, and apologies for
a hasty note,
